title: 111_hr6538
content:
The "Permanent Tax Relief Act of 2010" repeals certain tax relief acts and provides permanent relief for individual Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT). The "Permanent Tax Relief Act of 2010" amends the exemption amount for taxpayers other than corporations under section 55(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Permanent Tax Relief Act of 2010" adjusts exemption amounts for different taxpayer categories under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. For unmarried individuals and surviving spouses, the exemption is 50 percent of the specified amount. For married individuals filing separately, the exemption is the full amount. Estates and trusts have a fixed exemption of $22,500. The term "surviving spouse" is defined in section 2(a), and marital status is determined under section 7703. For taxpayers in paragraph (1)(A), the exemption amounts are adjusted under the "Permanent Tax Relief Act of 2010" in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The exemption amounts for taxable years from 2010 to 2017 are as follows:
2010 - $72,450
2011 - $74,450
2012 - $78,250
2013 - $81,450
2014 - $85,050
2015 - $88,650
2016 - $92,650
2017 - $96,550 In 2017, the exemption amount was $96,550, which increased to $100,950 in 2018, $105,150 in 2019, and $109,950 in 2020. Taxpayers described in paragraph (1)(B) for tax purposes. The exemption amount for taxable years from 2010 to 2017 is as follows: $47,450 in 2010, $48,450 in 2011, $50,350 in 2012, $51,950 in 2013, $53,750 in 2014, $55,550 in 2015, $57,550 in 2016, and $59,500 in 2017. The exemption amount increased steadily from $59,500 in 2017 to $66,200 in 2020. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to limit the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year based on the taxpayer's regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55(a). Conforming amendments are made to the Adoption credit sections of the Code. Section 23(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the credit limitations for taxable years, allowing excess credits to be carried over to the following year. Additionally, the Child tax credit section is revised. The Child tax credit section of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to remove paragraph (3) and make adjustments to references to other sections. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust various tax credits, including the credit for interest on certain home mortgages, the savers' credit, and the residential energy efficient property credit. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust various tax credits, including the credit for interest on certain home mortgages, the savers' credit, and the residential energy efficient property credit. Subsection (a) exceeding the limitation imposed by section 26(a) for the taxable year will be carried over to the succeeding year and added to the credit allowable under subsection (a) for that year. Certain plug-in electric vehicles and alternative motor vehicle credits are also modified. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust various tax credits, including the credit for interest on home mortgages, the savers' credit, and the residential energy efficient property credit. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall be treated as a credit allowable under subpart A for that year. Additionally, the new qualified plug-in electric vehicle credit and foreign tax credit are also modified. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust various tax credits, including the foreign tax credit and the first-time home buyer credit for the District of Columbia. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009.
